item.name: Abalone
item.comment:
Abalone feels like a beautiful, tactical wresting match.
I find it nearly impossible to think several moves ahead in this game, so instead I focus on creating strong formations, making this a more tactical and very visual game, which I love.
Also, the clacking of the marbles is so satisfying!
I also find it aesthetically pleasing, and it's the only game I have on display outside of its box.
We don't play many abstracts lately, but I still have great fondness for this game, and it can take a game or two to really get into it, which is why we've added it to our 10x10 challenge for 2017.

item.name: Arboretum
item.comment:
I love the tantalizing decisions in this game! The game play is so simple: Draw 2, Play 1, Discard 1... but it feels so HARD! I don't want to give up ANY of my cards!
The scoring quirk (1's beating 8's) is a bit weird to explain the first time, but it feels so necessary to creating some of the great moments of the game.
I've docked this .5 points since we've house-ruled it so that all players get equal turns (per a suggestion from Jon Gets Games).
Also, beautiful artwork.

item.name: Castle Crush!
item.comment:
In the build phase, I like the tension between building a tall and vulnerable tower worth many points, versus a short sturdy tower worth fewer points. (And if you build a tall tower, someone else may be earning some of those points when they knock it over!) It's fun to build, experiment, and decide how risky you want to be.
Then, you take turns bashing each other's castles, which is just hilarious. This game produces a lot of laughs.
The game also works to keep the competition close, by awarding the currently-last place person the opportunity to bash first (and target those tall towers!) and choose new blocks first (when it comes time to re-build).
I find that this game is fun to play with just about anyone. You can play with kids, adults, gamers, non-gamers, and a mix of all of the above. It's inherently fun to build and crush, no matter how "well" you're doing. You're inspired to try your best, but you can't feel too badly when things don't turn out for you. And cheering after a big or surprising crush is a hoot.
This is one of my favorites, if not the crown jewel of my collection.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment: I really hope this gets a beautiful deluxe version someday.

item.name: Concordia
item.comment: I love this game. In no particular order, 10 things I love: 1. Quick to learn. Short rule book! Intuitive to play. 2. It is a game of abundance, not famine. 3. There are many great options to choose from each turn, rather than a feeling of needing to identify 1 ideal move. 4. There are several ways to get the things you want; and if you still don't like those options, you can pivot your strategy and focus on getting something else. 5. Scoring happens at the END of the game, so you can remain engaged and optimistic about your chances throughout the game. 6. The replay-ability looks to be great. 7. I like the 90-minute play time. Feels not short and not long. 8. Plays well with 2! 9. The game is beautiful on the table. 10. Even though the artwork on the box cover is not great, I still appreciate that it's a woman on the cover who isn't over-sexualized.

item.name: Crossing
item.comment:
High luck, low strategy, and some laughs with the right crowd. My go-to bar games are Skull and Ghost Blitz, but I'm happy to have this option for folks who don't enjoy bluffing or speed, and are still intimidated by strategy.
This is a game I bought not for me, but for certain audiences. Looking forward to playing this at Thanksgiving with my niece and parents!
I also love the art style, and appreciate the representation of female characters.

item.name: A Fake Artist Goes to New York
Pandemic Legacy: Season 1
item.comment: My only disappointment was how the ending was presented. Otherwise, I am thankful for the memorable ride it gave us. The Legacy aspect of it certainly heightened the stakes, which created higher highs and lower lows than our typical game play. It was a special experience for us to share with friends over the course of a year.

item.name: Pictomania
item.comment: Brilliant, chaotic tension between wanting to draw fast so that you can guess at others' drawings quickly, but wanting to draw accurately (slower) so that others will guess yours correctly. Add to that the twist of having to guess from a list of similar items. Without having played them all, I declare this the best drawing game.

item.name: Q‚Ä¢bitz Extreme
item.comment: I love playing this game, and am very good at it. Unfortunately, that means I totally crush most people I play against (except my friend Gina, and sometimes my wife, Kate), which creates awkward moments while sitting and waiting for other people to finish. I can play with a handicap, but that still feels a bit awkward.

item.name: Scythe
item.comment:
After 20+ plays: I love this game at every player count I've played. (2, 3, 4, 5).
At 2-player on a pre-determined map, yes, you can avoid each other and more or less freely roam, but I still feel the tension of having to produce stars and hex control as fast as possible, as I watch my opponent's each move and guess their trajectory, wondering how many turns I have left to get it done.
Then at higher player counts- oof! wow. A different game. Territory is precious, and getting around can quickly get tricky. With experienced players, turns can whip around super fast.
The whole, "it's not so much about combat, as it is about the threat of combat" is so true and so great. Just the threat has totally messed with my plans; it's a mind game! The more I play, the more I appreciate this.
Replayability continues to be amazing, largely thanks to being able to play different combos of player mat and faction, plus the variability in what you're playing against (factions, mats, amount of players)- and so many different paths to victory. Every game, to have a shot at winning, I have to take a fresh look at what my best approach might be. Cherry on top is the achievements that push you to try to win under certain restrictions/conditions; with as much experience as we have now, we've won under some surprising conditions! (Including my wife, winning with less than 6 popularity!!)
Scythe also meets my criteria for having gender parity in the roles, then gets bonus points for having more women than men!
More bonus points for Jamey Stegmaier creating community around his game, and being super involved. You can ask a question in one of his Facebook groups, and have it answered in minutes, often by Jamey himself.
And finally, the quality components and original artwork elevate everything.

item.name: Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective: The Thames Murders & Other Cases
Splendor
item.comment:
This is my go-to temperature check to see whether a muggle wants to be a a witch.
An elegant game, distilled to only the essential parts.

item.name: Star Wars: Destiny
item.comment:
My first CCG.
Each set and various metas are bound to produce different opinions from me, but on the whole, I love the concept, structure, pace, look/feel, variety of strategies, ability to experiment, and theme of this game. Also- it's wonderful to be a part of a local community surrounding it!

item.name: Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game ‚Äì Heroes of the Resistance Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game ‚Äì Imperial Aces Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game ‚Äì K-wing Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game ‚Äì Rebel Aces Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game ‚Äì Sabine's TIE Fighter Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game ‚Äì T-70 X-Wing Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game ‚Äì The Force Awakens Core Set
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game ‚Äì TIE Defender Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game ‚Äì TIE Fighter Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game ‚Äì VT-49 Decimator Expansion Pack
Wits & Wagers
item.comment:
An effective "game for non-gamers" option.
I brought this to Christmas at my sister's. My brother-in-law and sister initially declined to play, so we started playing without them. However, as soon as we read the first question aloud, they both perked up and started pondering the answer aloud. So we handed them each a whiteboard and a marker, said, "here, write your answer on this," and then they were playing and having fun!
